nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) misrepresents long-term technological energy transitions and produces artifact results such as monotonically increasing carbon prices
CES functions are share-preserving and imply that substituting a dominant factor requires exponentially increasing amounts of the substitute as substitution progresses

When applied to technical factor inputs (e.g., fossil fuel versus renewable energy) CES produces substitution trajectories and marginal rates of technical substitution that conflict with historically observed S-curve technology diffusion
The CES-driven substitution behavior translates into an exponentially increasing carbon tax trajectory needed to force substitution, an artifact rather than a physical or technical necessity

Policy reliance on IAM outputs that use CES leads to three practical distortions for energy policy: price diversion (overemphasis on pricing), sticker shock (perception of prohibitively high costs), and technological myopia (favoring technologies already in model shares)

Mathematical derivation and the MRTS expression for CES show marginal rate of technical substitution depends on the factor ratio and elasticity parameter, leading to exponential replacement requirements for positive rho
Empirical history of technology and energy transitions follows S-curve (logistic, Gompertz, Bass) diffusion with increasing ease of substitution during deployment, not CES-like increasing difficulty
CES cannot represent dynamically changing elasticity of substitution inherent in S-curve technical diffusion without explicit modification

A stylized numerical example applying CES to substitute fossil energy with renewable energy shows: (i) RE quantities must grow exponentially to replace F, (ii) substitution saturates far from complete, (iii) carbon price is small initially then increases exponentially, and (iv) carbon price is highly sensitive to elasticity
Literature sampling and historical data across sectors and energy transitions (cited studies) consistently show exponential deployment and cost reduction patterns that align with S-curve diffusion
A practical modification—dynamically varying the elasticity of substitution over time—can produce S-curve-like substitution within existing model frameworks and avoids CES artifacts

Examples of mainstream IAMs and hybrid models (e.g., GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, GCAM, MERGE) that use nested CES or variants produce exponentially rising carbon price estimates (hundreds to thousands USD/tCO2) and limited renewable penetration without backstop technologies

Recommendation: replace or augment CES-based economic substitution in IAMs with either dynamically varying-elasticity formulations calibrated to technical diffusion or fundamentally physical energy models that set deployment targets and capture physical constraints
